awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Team-Mentored Interdisciplinary Research Experiences in Chemistry for Early-Stage Undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of North Texas (UNT) is located in Denton, TX. The site is led by Profs. LeGrande Slaughter and Hong Wang. It supports the training of 8 students over 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. It is funded by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Science Directorate. Student scientists focus on collaborative and interdisciplinary team-mentored research projects. The student participants are co-advised by two or more chemistry research groups. They also take part in professional development activities. These are designed to foster knowledge of career opportunities in chemical research, ethical issues in science, and scientific communication skills. This REU Site targets early-stage science majors who have not yet experienced research. The program also builds upon and strengthens UNT Chemistry's network of faculty partners in the underserved Texas/South Central/New Mexico region. This will help to recruit students from undergraduate-focused institutions, including several Hispanic-serving institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. 

The research projects designed for participants are highly interdisciplinary. They encompass joint computational/experimental studies of selective organometallic catalysts and synthesis of new materials by soft-landing mass spectrometry. The also include studies of corrosion mechanisms in electronic devices, and pi-extended porphyrin materials for dye-sensitized solar cells. The focus on team mentoring prepares participants to make substantive independent research contributions within a collaborative team setting. It enables them to thrive in the increasingly collaborative world of modern scientific research. Research training is coupled with career development activities addressing communication skills, career development, scientific ethics, and public outreach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many crucial scientific advances that underpin our modern quality of life - from technologies that steadily increase the density of transistors on the next generation of computer microchips, to medical treatments that revolutionize the fight against devastating diseases like cancer - increasingly depend on collaborations between scientists from different disciplines. However, undergraduate students who might consider careers in research are rarely provided any instruction, much less any direct experience, in the skills required to become successful collaborative researchers. This is a problem, because employers in sectors ranging from industry to medicine increasingly expect new researchers to quickly adapt to a highly interdisciplinary work environment that requires extensive collaboration.

This project created a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site in the Chemistry Department at the University of North Texas that aimed to immerse early-stage college students in team-mentored, interdisciplinary research projects at the forefront of the chemical sciences. By engaging students in exciting research projects that span multiple chemistry disciplines early in their undergraduate careers, the organizers of this REU Site sought to better equip students to pursue advanced scientific degrees and attain impactful research careers. This will create positive outcomes in students' careers while contributing to a more innovative and effective scientific workforce.

For each of three summers (2019, 2022, and 2023, with a two-year pause due to the COVID pandemic), a group of eight REU Scholars was selected from a nationwide pool, using a holistic recruitment process that focused on students' creativity, resilience, and motivation for gaining research experience. Each REU Scholar was assigned a Core Mentoring Team (CMT) that guided and trained the student as they gained the skills and knowledge needed to make substantive progress in an interdisciplinary research project related to their scientific interests. Each CMT comprised a UNT Chemistry faculty member who served as primary mentor, one or two secondary mentors (usually another UNT faculty member, but sometimes a industrial or academic collaborator), and at least one in-lab mentor, a graduate student or postdoc who worked with the student daily to provide oversight and encouragement. Over the 10-week summer program, the REU Scholars learned to work collaboratively while researching projects ranging from light-induced copper etching in microelectronic devices, to synthesis of new porous materials for direct air capture of carbon dioxide, to biosynthesis of medicinally interesting fungal natural products, to developing predictive models for detection of dangerous illicit drugs such as fentanyl. These collaborative projects have resulted in 11 peer-reviewed papers with UNT Chemistry REU Scholars as co-authors over the 2019-2023 period, as well as 22 presentations given by REU Scholars at major scientific conferences.

The REU Site combined accelerated technical training, including a series of "Research Boot Camps" that imparted skills in computational chemistry, NMR spectroscopy, and other techniques, with a robust professional development program designed to impart "soft skills" necessary for successful careers in research. This included a strong focus on scientific communication skills, with required poster and oral presentations, as well as an intensive mini-course on scientific ethics, networking opportunities with industry researchers, and discussions on inclusivity in the scientific workforce with researchers from a variety of backgrounds. Peer-review sessions were held before the required presentations, helping students to build confidence in their presentation skills while strengthening the program's focus on collaboration.

The program focused its recruiting efforts on students from non-PhD-granting, primarily undergraduate colleges and universities, which often have limited or no resources for supporting undergraduate research. Over the award period, 92% of participants were from such institutions. 75% of participants were early-stage students who had completed no more than two years of college, ensuring that the REU Site experience had potential for transformative impacts on their educational and career outcomes.  In addition, the program saw significant participation from students in historically underrepresented groups, including eight Hispanic or Latino students, one African American student, and 11 women.

The program has been successful in preparing participants for significant educational and career achievements, as indicated by a high rate of enrollment in graduate and professional programs. Six of the 13 participants who graduated have entered doctoral programs in chemistry or related fields, many at highly regarded institutions such as the University of Illinois. A majority of program participants are expected to attend graduate school based on post-program evaluations in which 86% of respondents indicated that participation had solidified or increased their interest in graduate studies. Two former REU Scholars are in dental or pharmacy school, and three are working in research-related jobs.

The broader impacts of this REU Site on society include preparing a cohort of young scientists to conduct collaborative, innovative research that drives economically valuable new technologies; increasing the diversity of students pursuing advanced degrees in science; developing team-mentoring and peer review as integral components of undergraduate research training; and disseminating creative, interdisciplinary research that pushes the frontiers of new knowledge.
